title: Electric PE - four systems with two point charges

content.question:
Consider four different systems each consisting of a pair of point charges. The point charges in the systems have the following charge values and separation distances.

System <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>: point charges of <math alttext="positive 1 nanocoulomb" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mpadded><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>nC</mi></math> and <math alttext="positive 1 nanocoulomb" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mpadded><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>nC</mi></math>, separated by <math alttext="1 centimeter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math>

System <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>: point charges of <math alttext="positive 1 nanocoulomb" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mpadded><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>nC</mi></math> and <math alttext="positive 4 nanocoulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn></mpadded><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>nC</mi></math>, separated by <math alttext="4 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math>

System <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>: point charges of <math alttext="negative 1 nanocoulomb" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mpadded></mpadded><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>nC</mi></math> and <math alttext="positive 6 nanocoulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn></mpadded><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>nC</mi></math>, separated by <math alttext="1 centimeter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math>

System <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math>: point charges of <math alttext="positive 2 nanocoulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mpadded><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mpadded></mpadded></mpadded><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>nC</mi></math> and <math alttext="positive 2 nanocoulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mpadded><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>nC</mi></math>, separated by <math alttext="2 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math>

Which of the following correctly ranks the electric potential energies <math alttext="U sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="U sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="U sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>, and <math alttext="U sub 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mn>4</mn></msub></math> of the four systems? Take the potential energy of a system to be zero when the point charges are infinitely far apart.

choices.label: <math alttext="U sub 1 equals U sub 4, which is greater than U sub 2, which is greater than U sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>U</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>U</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>U</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>

<math alttext="U sub 2 equals U sub 3, which is greater than U sub 4, which is greater than U sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>U</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>U</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>U</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>

<math alttext="U sub 2 equals U sub 4, which is greater than U sub 1, which is greater than U sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>U</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>U</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>U</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>

<math alttext="U sub 4 is greater than U sub 1, which equals U sub 2, which is greater than U sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>U</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>U</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>U</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="U sub 4 is greater than U sub 1, which equals U sub 2, which is greater than U sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>U</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>U</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>U</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>
